item.title: British Lawmaker's Killing Highlights Continued Terrorism Challenge in U.K.
item.description: The fatal stabbing of David Amess by a suspected extremist shows the difficulties facing the government in preventing lone-wolf attacks.

item.title: Islamic State Bombing Kills at Least 65 People in Southern Afghanistan
item.description: The killings in Kandahar, the Taliban’s historic stronghold, follow a spate of Islamic State attacks on the country’s religious minority sect.

item.title: Nigeria's Criminal Gangs Steal Munitions and Extort the Government
item.description: In the forests of northwest Nigeria, loosely organized criminal gangs that raised funds kidnapping schoolchildren are now flush with arms and operating beyond the reach of an increasingly fragile state.

item.title: Some Sell Children as Afghanistan Sinks Into Destitution
item.description: Poverty in Afghanistan is worsening fast after the Taliban seized power and most foreign aid ended. Already, 95% of Afghans aren’t getting enough to eat, the U.N. warns.

item.title: Myanmar's Military Junta Denied a Seat at Asean Summit
item.description: The regional bloc’s decision effectively sidelines Myanmar’s bid for international legitimacy and increases pressure on the country to cooperate with its neighbors to resolve its political crisis.

item.title: Inflation Sets Off Alarms Around the World
item.description: More than a dozen central banks have raised interest rates but two that haven’t are those that loom largest over the global economy: the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank.
